text: Yeah, look, I echo Andrew's sentiments. I'd actually been pushing for this, for training of this nature or some form of assistance for probably the better part of what have been 18 months or so, I think, Kirsty, it had been about that length of time. And through various, for various reasons that had been put off or delayed or COVID obviously played a big role in that.  My motivation, I suppose, in asking for and pushing for that training was that it became pretty clear quite early on to me that there was a very large range of people's understandings of, firstly, the history, specifically in our area, which during our induction, I have to acknowledge Shane was amazing at trying to upscale and bring up to speed some of our members who were lacking in that space.  On a broader context, it was obvious to me that there were quite significant vacuums in understanding around the broader issues of the colonization of New Zealand and the history behind the treaty and what led to the treaty and what led after the treaty. And it was a really, as far as ground works, who were the outfit that presented to us, I thought it was a really, neutral's not quite the right word, but it was very,  It was very conversational, very blunt, but quite a sort of safe kind of environment to try and understand when you've got people who are quite well-versed at one end of the spectrum to those who really don't know, and dare I say it, don't possibly have too much interest of their own accord in the whole subject. So I thought it was a really, really valuable experience. And I guess from where I sit,  and it's become clear to me that there are kind of two parallel kind of questions or issues in play here. One is local government's jurisprudential kind of situation. It's legal obligations, you know, that bundle of obligations that we have there. Like, what does that look like? And I guess from an elected member's perspective, I don't really know. So I still want to have that clarified. So that's kind of one bundle over here. And then over here,  we've got this moral collection of obligations potentially, and that's related specifically to Waipā and connected to what happened here and the people that we live alongside, you know, and amongst. And under that, we're only allowed entitled to one. So only those on the Māori electoral roll will be entitled to vote for the Māori Ward councillor. And so unfortunately, the next option to change roles is in,  potentially, likely 2023, potentially 2024. So that's not, if anyone's on the roll, that's not very helpful in terms of if they want to change over to the Māori roll to be able to vote for the Māori ward member for the local body elections. So unfortunately, that doesn't really  link up in terms of timing. So this is just a bit of a look at our  stats. We have got pretty good stats in terms of number enrolled across our district of those that are eligible. We're sitting at 93 percent. We have 2,487 on the Māori roll, so that'll give you an indication of how many people will be entitled to vote for that Māori ward member.  And we've got that 2837 not currently enrolled, so hopefully we'll be able to get some more of those on the roll before the roll closes.  So just a bit of information on Māori war candidates. So you don't need to be Māori. You are all on the Māori electoral roll or even live in Waipā. So you just must be a New Zealand citizen on the electoral roll somewhere. And you will have to be nominated by two electors eligible to vote for the Waipā Māori roll. So it's someone that's on the Māori roll  or two people on the Māori roll in Waipā will need to nominate any Māori ward candidate. There's just a few restrictions about being a candidate that apply across the board. In relation to having contracts with council, over 25,000, there is a exemption process  with the Office of the Auditor-General. You can't be a council employee, but you could be a council employee at the time that you go through the process. And then if you were successful, you would need to resign and being subject to court orders under Section 31.  of the Protection of Property Rights Act that's in relation to an appointment of manager when you're not considered by the family court to be able to manage your own affairs that section.  We have a standard nomination form that needs to be completed, a $200 fee for putting in your nomination and candidates are also able to put in a picture and a candidate profile statement. text: So I just wanted to, so Ngāi Topu has maintained its own mana around Ngā Roto, and this is stemmed from  Uncle Fred Porima in his time. So one of the things that Uncle Fred was always very apprehensive about in Ngaroto, and that is the lowering of the water levels at Ngaroto. He was quite opposed to that. So Ngāri Toke has always stood by that stance and that's sheerly through the  Historical, because it stands back from Tuuanuku and then it stands back to the kaitiaki of that time. And so I just wanted to remind everybody that's always been the stance of Ngāi Tōpū and it's the water levels at Ngā Roto.
speaker: gayleneroberts

text: And I suppose leading on from that, and it's just not Ngā Roto, but it's all of our peak lakes have now had their water levels set in terms of a regional resource consent. And so, you know,  you know, in the past, the water levels were kept high in Ngaroto over the summer period and then drained out over the winter, which is the complete reverse of what happens naturally. But that has now been remedied in terms of setting the water level. People around that own property around the lake and finches have been mentioned here,  that if they continue to cultivate the peat soils around the lake, we'll only be able to do that for a short period of time because every time you cultivate the peat soil, they oxidize and shrink effectively.  So they will, in effect, be extending the size of Ngā Roto because the lake will actually flood onto their property. And that's what's happened on the inlet end, I suppose, of the lake where a large proportion of that dairy farm that adjoins the lake there is now pretty much unusable over the winter period because of the flooding that occurs there.  I've been involved personally over probably 30 years trying to improve the quality of the water in Lake Ngaroto and other peat lakes around the district. And Council's invested really heavily in  sorting out boundary issues, I suppose, doing boundary swaps to try and get the best esplanade or reserve around the lake that we can, fencing it off, planting it, and putting in silt traps and things like that. But there's still a huge amount of work that needs to be done. And you're right, Bill, it's nothing that iwi have done that,  made that water deteriorate, it's runoff from farming activities around the lake, whether it be direct from cow sheds or fertilizer or just stock runoff. So until we can control that, then chances of a notable improvement is probably pretty slim.  And I've dealt with all sorts of experts over the years that have come up with ideas, some of which I thought would work, but for various reasons, scientists said no, and from a cultural perspective may not have been appropriate, such as dredging the sediment, which is basically  farm effluent really at the bottom of the lake and topsoil that's run off because of the cultivation of those areas around the lake. But there are issues, practical and cultural, that dredging it may not have been an option, but it  looking at it and with my experience, it's going to be something radical that needs to be done if we're going to ever try and get that lake back to a reasonably environmentally sustainable system.
